questions.question: In the experiment, what does the flow rate (LPM) represent?

answers.a: The radial velocity of the slider
answers.b: The amount of water passing through the system per minute
answers.c: The angular velocity of the rotating link
answers.d: The tangential velocity of the slider

explanations.a: The radial velocity is the velocity along the radius, not the flow rate.
explanations.b: The flow rate (LPM) represents the amount of water passing through the system per minute.
explanations.c: The angular velocity refers to the rotation rate, not the flow rate.
explanations.d: Tangential velocity is related to the speed along the circumference, not the flow rate.

questions.question: If the radial velocity is zero, what will the Coriolis acceleration be?

explanations.a: If radial velocity is zero, Coriolis acceleration will not be maximum.
explanations.b: Coriolis acceleration is zero if there is no radial velocity.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration is not equal to angular velocity when radial velocity is zero.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration is defined when radial velocity is zero—it just equals zero.

questions.question: What does the torque measurement in the hydraulic system indicate?

answers.b: The angular velocity of the rotating link
answers.c: The rotational force needed to overcome resistance in the fluid system

explanations.a: Torque is related to force, not directly to power.
explanations.b: Torque does not directly indicate angular velocity.
explanations.c: Torque measures the rotational force needed to overcome resistance in the fluid system.
explanations.d: Torque is not directly related to the slider velocity.

questions.question: In the virtual experiment, what happens if you do not lock the parameter values before starting the simulation?

answers.a: The simulation will fail to start.
answers.b: The system will use default values for parameters.
answers.c: The simulation will start with incorrect values.

explanations.a: The simulation does not fail to start if parameters are not locked.
explanations.b: If parameters are not locked, the system uses default values.
explanations.c: The simulation does not start with incorrect values, it defaults them.
explanations.d: The simulation will not crash due to unlocked parameters.

questions.question: How can the Coriolis effect be visually observed in the virtual lab?

answers.a: Through vector arrows showing acceleration components
answers.c: By adjusting the slider’s position manually

explanations.a: Vector arrows representing acceleration components show the Coriolis effect.
explanations.b: Torque does not directly show the Coriolis effect.
explanations.c: Manually adjusting the slider does not visually show the Coriolis effect.
explanations.d: Increasing the flow rate does not directly visualize the Coriolis effect.

questions.question: What conclusion can be drawn from the Coriolis acceleration experiment?

answers.a: Radial velocity and angular velocity have no effect on acceleration.
answers.b: Coriolis acceleration depends linearly on both radial and angular velocities.
answers.c: Coriolis acceleration decreases with increasing angular velocity.
answers.d: Radial motion does not contribute to Coriolis acceleration.

explanations.a: Both radial and angular velocities affect Coriolis acceleration.
explanations.b: Coriolis acceleration depends linearly on both radial and angular velocities.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration increases with increasing angular velocity.
explanations.d: Radial motion contributes to Coriolis acceleration.

questions.question: How is the Coriolis acceleration affected if the angular velocity is doubled?

explanations.a: Coriolis acceleration does not become half if angular velocity is doubled.
explanations.b: Coriolis acceleration changes when angular velocity is altered.
explanations.c: Coriolis acceleration doubles if angular velocity is doubled.
explanations.d: Coriolis acceleration does not quadruple with angular velocity.
